!WX7}jO5U`owfsCtbOAw.text:
Basic scrolling engine by @griffpatch, significantly enhcanced by @FunnyAnimatorJimTV

GENERAL TOUR:

---

Close South/East: Important, Top Scripts, for Movement, Cappy Throwing, Enemy Detecting, Etc.

Far South: Short, Less Important Scripts

Far East: Special Actions, like GroundPound, Longjump, Flame bounce, etc.

---

Everything is triggered from this "Do Player Tick" block on the left. This block runs over and over and tells Mario what to do on every frame.

The "Move Player sx sy" Moves Mario where he needs a movement change.

The "When Y key pressed" triggers all actions associted with the Y key.

When Mario is on the ground, the (falling) variable is 0.

The "SPECIAL" variable holds what special action Mario is doing, such as a GroundPound, Longjump, Vaulting, or even Flameboucing.

*QK]e!|e-SO,?m2jAeML.text:
^^^

Those 4 scripts up there are the ones needing a change when adding a new capture target

WWZyr79m{Dp0QvS#QQc/.text:
Credit to @griffpatch

To make your own level, you need to have good costume names. The way this project works is that the position of the costumes in the level depends on their names.

We use the numbes 0-9 to do this.

For example, my level goes like this:

10

00     01     02


See how the '10' costume goes above the '00' costume, and the '01' and '02' costumes come to the right of '00'? This is the way you name your costumes.

You need to do this for the "Art" costumes as well. The "Collision" sprite is what Mario actually stands on, while the Art has all the fancy details. The art sprite uses the same method for numbering of the costumes.

)p8~Ur,MAVPL%2mqsX9W.text:
Credit to @griffpatch

To make your own level, you need to have good costume names. The way this project works is that the position of the costumes in the level depends on their names.

We use the numbes 0-9 to do this.

For example, my level goes like this:

10

00     01     02


See how the '10' costume goes above the '00' costume, and the '01' and '02' costumes come to the right of '00'? This is the way you name your costumes.

You need to do this for the "Collision" costumes as well. The "Collision" sprite is what Mario actually stands on, not the Art. Collision is really important, and uses the same method for numbering of the costumes.

PYu^!24i]wdVCZX2lUF@.text: To add a new moon, (this applies to groundpound moons as well) do:Set Moon XSet Moon YSet size to 80Create cloneSet size to 100Create cloneAnd put it at the end of this script
